Problem:
Suppose there is a function \\(z(x, t)\\) governed by the partial differential equation (PDE) \\(\\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} + x \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial x} = 0\\) where x represents space and t represents time. An intervention \\(h(x, t)\\) is defined as \\(z(x, t) = u(x, t) + v(x, t)\\), with \\(u(x, t)\\) and \\(v(x, t)\\) being solutions to another set of PDEs.

Can we determine which specific intervention (either addition or subtraction of \\(u(x, t)\\) and \\(v(x, t)\\)) was applied by only observing \\(z(x, T)\\) at a final time \\(T\\) and knowing the form of the original PDE?
Explanation: Without knowing the specific details of the intervention (whether addition or subtraction was applied), the observed outcome \\(z(x, T)\\) does not uniquely determine the nature of the intervention, owing to linearity and potential symmetry in the roles of \\(u(x, t)\\) and \\(v(x, t)\\).
